topics.title: Product-led sales requires new internal collaboration
topics.summary: Elena contrasts traditional sales org structure with product-led sales, where product is accountable for acquiring/activating users and creating pipeline for sales. She warns that trying to run PLG/PLS purely from marketing is a fast path to failure.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Elena Verna, her experience, and what the episode will cover: a deep dive into product-led sales, how it differs from PLG/SLG, and how to implement it.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Linear and Braintrust.

topics.title: Elena’s current work and advising availability
topics.summary: Elena shares she wrapped her interim role at Amplitude, is taking a break between interim gigs, and is advising companies while building new frameworks. She’s open to conversations but not actively sourcing clients.

topics.title: Defining product-led sales vs product-led growth
topics.summary: Elena defines PLG as self-serve acquisition/activation/engagement and value capture, and explains PLS as converting self-serve usage into sales-led expansion. She notes self-serve monetization caps around ~$10k, making sales necessary for larger contracts.

topics.title: Individual-to-enterprise escalator and enterprise value
topics.summary: Elena explains PLS assumes an “escalator” from individual job-to-be-done to enterprise-level outcomes (e.g., Amplitude: insights → data-driven culture). Sales bridges the gap because products often fail to communicate enterprise value clearly.

topics.title: When sales is needed: motivation, ability, permission
topics.summary: Elena frames when to involve sales using user motivation/ability/permission: users may lack authority or capability to drive enterprise adoption. Sales (and marketing) help assemble stakeholders, overcome friction, and enable internal selling.

topics.title: Examples: Miro and Figma enterprise problem statements
topics.summary: Elena illustrates how products start with individual/team use cases but monetize at enterprise level (Miro: workshops → org productivity/innovation; Figma: design feedback → better business outcomes). She argues products should increasingly communicate enterprise value, not only sales.

topics.title: Why hand-raisers plateau and pipeline must be created
topics.summary: Elena explains many PLG companies start PLS by responding to inbound enterprise requests, but this demand quickly dries up. The real work is converting usage into pipeline by finding decision-makers outside the user base and connecting them to product value.

topics.title: Who should invest in product-led sales
topics.summary: Elena says PLS effectively means going upmarket (often $15k+ ACV and into mid-market/enterprise). Products focused on freelancers/startups may not benefit because buyers are price-sensitive and prefer self-serve without sales involvement.

topics.title: Two paths to PLS: from PLG upmarket or SLG downmarket
topics.summary: Elena outlines two adoption paths: PLG companies add sales to move upmarket; SLG companies add product-led elements to scale downmarket or meet buyers who demand value before purchase. PLS helps reduce cost of sale and/or de-risk enterprise buying.

topics.title: Product must own monetization and pipeline creation
topics.summary: Elena reiterates SLG companies must add product-assisted/PLG capabilities or risk disruption, and argues B2B product teams have ceded monetization ownership to sales/marketing. She describes product owning self-serve revenue (often via growth teams) and owning product-created pipeline thresholds for sales.

topics.title: PQA vs PQL vs MQL and three lead paths
topics.summary: Elena defines product-qualified accounts (usage-based account signals), product-qualified leads (a buyer within the user base), and marketing-qualified leads (buyer sourced by marketing/sales). She explains three paths: usage+buyer, usage+no buyer (need to find decision-maker), and buyer+no usage (top-down).

topics.title: Avoid jamming PLS into top-down sales motions
topics.summary: Elena warns against treating new sign-ups like traditional MQLs and immediately pushing sales outreach, creating a mismatched journey (memes: The Shining/urinal). PLG starts with individual intent, while top-down sales assumes enterprise intent at the bottom of the funnel.

topics.title: Building PLS: data approach and PQA modeling
topics.summary: Elena recommends starting with sales intuition and lightweight analysis before buying tooling, to avoid flooding sales with low-quality leads. She suggests iterating PQA definitions with tight sales feedback loops, then scaling via regression/automation once the model is understood.

topics.title: Common PQA signals: users, volume, velocity, behaviors
topics.summary: Elena shares common predictors for sales engagement: number of users (often a “7 users” threshold), usage volume (events/boards/revisions), and velocity changes. She adds behavioral signals like admin changes and visits to terms/privacy pages as strong indicators of enterprise evaluation.

topics.title: Over-outreach risks: channel saturation and user trust
topics.summary: Elena argues aggressive sales outreach can desensitize users to key channels (email/in-app), reducing responsiveness when timing is actually right. She emphasizes protecting the user journey and using outreach thoughtfully to preserve attention and trust.
